System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.

A proper ideal $\mathfrak{m} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a maximal ideal if for any ideal $\mathfrak{a} \subset R$ that contains $\mathfrak{m}$, $\mathfrak{a}$ must be either $\mathfrak{m}$ or $R$.
Does the concept of a/an System of Generators of an Ideal need to be defined for a definition of a/an Maximal Ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The definition of a maximal ideal does not inherently require the concept of a system of generators of an ideal. A maximal ideal is defined purely in terms of containment relations between ideals within a ring. Specifically, a maximal ideal is defined as a proper ideal that is not contained in any larger proper ideal. This definition focuses on the structure and hierarchy of ideals within a ring, without reference to how these ideals are generated or what elements they contain.

On the other hand, the concept of a system of generators of an ideal deals with how an ideal can be expressed or constructed from elements of the ring. It specifies that an ideal can be generated by a set of elements, meaning that the ideal consists of all possible combinations (linear combinations with coefficients in the ring) of these elements. This concept is useful for understanding the internal structure of an ideal, but it is not necessary for defining what makes an ideal maximal.

Therefore, the concept of a maximal ideal can be fully understood and applied without needing to define or use the concept of a system of generators of an ideal. The two concepts operate on different aspects of ideals: one on the hierarchical position of an ideal within a ring and the other on the composition of the ideal itself.
